Question: I am a software engineer who has been working with a team for years now. We have had many discussions about how we can improve our codebase. One thing that always comes up is the fact that there are some people who don't like certain things or want to change something. It seems like they just want to be able to say "no" without having to justify it. This makes me uncomfortable because I know that if I'm going to make changes, I need to explain why I'm doing so. But sometimes I wonder if this is really necessary. If someone doesn't like something, shouldn't they be able to say "I don't like it"? Why should I have to defend myself? I've seen other teams where people will argue against an idea even when it's obvious that it's the right decision. Shouldn't everyone be able to express themselves freely?
Answer: I agree that it's important to listen to different points of view, but I also believe that it's equally important to give reasons for decisions. When you disagree with someone, it's easy to say "you're wrong," but it's much harder to say "here's why." The reason is that it takes time to come up with a good explanation, and it's hard to remember everything that went into making a decision. So, while it may seem like you're being defensive, you're actually giving yourself a chance to think through your position before you speak.
In my experience, most people are willing to hear out another point of view, especially if they understand that you're trying to help them see the bigger picture. However, if you keep saying "I'm right, and you're wrong," then you're essentially telling them that you don't care about their opinion. And that's not very helpful. You might as well just tell them to go away and stop bothering you. In any case, I think it's better to take the time to explain your reasoning behind a decision, even if it means taking longer to get to the end result. That way, you'll both learn from each other and hopefully come to a compromise that works for everyone involved.
